Basic storage, access, and manipulation of phylogenetic sequencing data with MicrobiomeExperiment

2020-10-25

Source: vignettes/MicrobiomeExperiment-basics.Rmd
MicrobiomeExperiment-basics.Rmd

Load MicrobiomeExperiment 

library("MicrobiomeExperiment")

Example Data

Example data consists mainly of phyloseq [(McMurdie and Holmes 2013)] datasets converted to SummarizedExperiment/TreeSummarizedExperiment objects.

data(GlobalPatterns)
data(esophagus)
data(enterotype)
data(soilrep)

MicrobiomeExperiment Object Summaries

Since MicrobiomeExperiment are TreeSummarizedExperiment experiment objects, the summary should look quite familiar.

data(GlobalPatterns)
me <- as(GlobalPatterns,"MicrobiomeExperiment")
me
## class: MicrobiomeExperiment 
## dim: 19216 26 
## metadata(0):
## assays(1): counts
## rownames(19216): 549322 522457 ... 200359 271582
## rowData names(7): Kingdom Phylum ... Genus Species
## colnames(26): CL3 CC1 ... Even2 Even3
## colData names(7): X.SampleID Primer ... SampleType Description
## reducedDimNames(0):
## altExpNames(0):
## rowLinks: a LinkDataFrame (19216 rows)
## rowTree: a phylo (19216 leaves)
## colLinks: NULL
## colTree: NULL
## referenceSeq: NULL

Functions for working microbiome data

Merging and agglomeration based on taxonomic information.

In addition to the aggValue functions provide by TreeSummarizedExperiment agglomerateByRank is available if, tree construction proves difficult.

agglomerateByRank constructs a factor to guide merging from the available taxonomic information. For more information on merging have a look at the man page via ?mergeRows.

# print the available taxonomic ranks
colnames(rowData(me))
## [1] "Kingdom" "Phylum"  "Class"   "Order"   "Family"  "Genus"   "Species"
taxonomyRanks(me)
## [1] "Kingdom" "Phylum"  "Class"   "Order"   "Family"  "Genus"   "Species"
# agglomerate at the Family taxonomic rank
x1 <- agglomerateByRank(me, rank = "Family")
## How many taxa before/after agglomeration?
nrow(me)
## [1] 19216
nrow(x1)
## [1] 603
# with agglomeration of the tree
x2 <- agglomerateByRank(me, rank = "Family",
                        agglomerateTree = TRUE)
nrow(x2) # same number of rows, but
## [1] 603
rowTree(x1) # ... different
## 
## Phylogenetic tree with 19216 tips and 19215 internal nodes.
## 
## Tip labels:
##   549322, 522457, 951, 244423, 586076, 246140, ...
## Node labels:
##   , 0.858.4, 1.000.154, 0.764.3, 0.995.2, 1.000.2, ...
## 
## Rooted; includes branch lengths.
rowTree(x2) # ... tree
## 
## Phylogenetic tree with 603 tips and 602 internal nodes.
## 
## Tip labels:
##   549322, 951, 244423, 143239, 215972, 138353, ...
## Node labels:
##   , 0.858.4, 1.000.154, 0.764.3, 0.995.2, 0.943.7, ...
## 
## Rooted; includes branch lengths.
## Look at enterotype dataset...
data(enterotype)
## print the available taxonomic ranks. Shows only 1 rank available
## not useful for agglomerateByRank
taxonomyRanks(enterotype)
## [1] "Genus"

To keep data tidy, the agglomerated data can be stored as an alternative experiment in the object of origin. With this synchronized sample subseting becomes very easy.

altExp(me, "family") <- x2

Keep in mind, that rows with NA or similar value (via the empty.fields argument) will be removed, if you set na.rm = FALSE. Depending on this different number of rows will be returned.

x1 <- agglomerateByRank(me, rank = "Species", na.rm = TRUE)
altExp(me,"species") <- agglomerateByRank(me, rank = "Species", na.rm = FALSE)
dim(x1)
## [1] 944  26
dim(altExp(me,"species"))
## [1] 2307   26

Constructing a tree from taxonomic data

taxa <- rowData(altExp(me,"species"))[,taxonomyRanks(me)]
taxa_res <- resolveLoop(as.data.frame(taxa))
taxa_tree <- toTree(data = taxa_res)
taxa_tree$tip.label <- getTaxonomyLabels(altExp(me,"species"))
rowNodeLab <- getTaxonomyLabels(altExp(me,"species"), makeUnique = FALSE)
altExp(me,"species") <- changeTree(altExp(me,"species"),
                                   rowTree = taxa_tree,
                                   rowNodeLab = rowNodeLab)

McMurdie, Paul J., and Susan Holmes. 2013. “Phyloseq: An R Package for Reproducible Interactive Analysis and Graphics of Microbiome Census Data.” PLoS ONE 8 (4): e61217. http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0061217.
